@graph.name: How to Grade Your Own Cards Before Sending to PSA
@graph.description: Step-by-step process to self-grade trading cards using PSA criteria before professional submission. Includes tools needed, inspection techniques, and decision framework.

supply.name: Card Centering Tool or Millimeter Ruler

step.name: Prepare Your Workspace
step.text: Clean your workspace and gather all necessary tools. Wash your hands and wear white cotton gloves to avoid fingerprints. Set up bright LED lighting overhead and at an angle.

step.name: Initial Visual Inspection
step.text: Examine the card under good lighting for any obvious flaws, creases, or damage. Check both front and back. If major flaws are found, stop here.

step.name: Measure Centering
step.text: Use a centering tool or ruler to measure the borders. Calculate left vs. right and top vs. bottom ratios. For PSA 10, front must be 55/45 to 60/40, back can be 70/30.

step.name: Inspect All Four Corners
step.text: Use a 10x loupe to examine each corner individually. Look for sharpness, rounding, or white edges. All four corners must be perfectly sharp for PSA 10.

step.name: Examine All Edges
step.text: Check all four edges for wear, fraying, or chipping. Hold the card at eye level under bright light. Use the loupe for close inspection.

step.name: Surface Inspection (Front and Back)
step.text: Systematically inspect the entire surface with a 10x loupe in a grid pattern. Look for print lines, scratches, scuffs, or surface damage on both the front AND back.

step.name: Assign Preliminary Grade
step.text: Based on your inspection of all four factors, assign a preliminary grade using the PSA 1-10 scale. Use the grading checklist to track findings.

step.name: Decide Whether to Grade
step.text: Use the 3x value rule: If the graded value won't be at least 3 times the grading cost, don't submit. Research expected graded values using eBay sold listings and PSA auction prices.

mainEntity.name: Can I grade cards as accurately as PSA?

acceptedAnswer.text: No, amateur collectors cannot grade as accurately as PSA's professional graders. PSA graders have years of training, specialized equipment, and handle thousands of cards annually. However, with practice and proper tools (10x loupe, centering tool), collectors can predict PSA grades within ±1 grade about 85% of the time. The goal of self-grading is to identify clear PSA 10 candidates and avoid submitting cards with obvious flaws, not to match PSA's exact grade.

mainEntity.name: What magnification do PSA graders use?

acceptedAnswer.text: PSA graders use 10x magnification loupes and magnifying lamps to inspect cards for surface flaws, corner wear, and edge issues. For accurate self-grading, collectors should use at least a 10x jeweler's loupe or magnifying glass, available for $15-$40 on Amazon. Using the same magnification as PSA ensures you see what they'll see.

mainEntity.name: How do I measure centering without a centering tool?

acceptedAnswer.text: To measure centering without a centering tool, use a standard ruler in millimeters: 1) Measure the left border width (e.g., 3mm), 2) Measure the right border width (e.g., 5mm), 3) Calculate the ratio: 3mm:5mm = 60/40, 4) Repeat for top and bottom borders, 5) Compare to PSA requirements (front: 55/45-60/40, back: up to 70/30). This DIY method is free and reasonably accurate with practice.

mainEntity.name: What's the most common self-grading mistake?

acceptedAnswer.text: The most common self-grading mistake is not measuring centering and instead eyeballing it. Centering accounts for 40% of PSA 10 rejections. Cards that look 'centered' to the naked eye are often 65/35 or 70/30 - too off-center for PSA 10. Always use a centering tool or ruler to measure precisely. The 5% difference between 60/40 (PSA 10 acceptable) and 65/35 (PSA 9) can mean thousands of dollars in value.

mainEntity.name: What's the difference between PSA 10 and PSA 9?

acceptedAnswer.text: The difference between PSA 10 and PSA 9 is usually ONE minor flaw: PSA 10 is perfect in all four categories (centering, corners, edges, surface). PSA 9 has ONE minor flaw such as one slightly soft corner (other three are sharp), centering 65/35 instead of 60/40, minor edge wear on one edge, or one small print line or surface issue. The value difference can be dramatic. Example: 1999 Charizard PSA 9 = $5,000-$8,000, PSA 10 = $300,000+.

mainEntity.name: How do I know if a card is a PSA 10 candidate?

acceptedAnswer.text: A card is a PSA 10 candidate if it meets ALL FOUR criteria: 1) Centering 55/45 to 60/40 on front (both axes), up to 70/30 on back, 2) All four corners perfectly sharp under 10x magnification, 3) All four edges clean with no fraying or chipping, 4) Flawless surface on both front AND back (no print lines, scratches, or damage). If ANY of these criteria fail, the card is not a PSA 10 candidate. Only 5-15% of modern submissions grade PSA 10.

mainEntity.name: Is it worth grading cards worth less than $100?

acceptedAnswer.text: It depends on the grading cost and expected grade. Use the 3x Value Rule: If grading costs $25 and the graded card will be worth $75+, it's borderline. If the graded card will be worth $100+, it's worth it. Example: Card worth $30 raw, $120 PSA 10 = Worth grading if PSA 10 candidate. Card worth $50 raw, $80 PSA 9 = Not worth grading (doesn't meet 3x rule). For most modern cards worth less than $100, grading is only worthwhile if you're confident in PSA 10.

mainEntity.name: What's the 3x rule for grading decisions?

acceptedAnswer.text: The 3x Value Rule states that a card should only be submitted for grading if the expected graded value will be at least 3 times the total cost of grading. Formula: Expected Graded Value ÷ Total Grading Cost ≥ 3. Example: Expected PSA 9 value $150, Total grading cost $30, Calculation: $150 ÷ $30 = 5x, Decision: YES submit. This ensures meaningful profit or collection value and accounts for the time, effort, and risk involved.
